We shouldn't confuse what ACA has done to increase access to healthcare insurance (payment) with the overall cost of healthcare in the US. The later has received relatively little attention. The fact remains the US in total pays considerably more of its GDP for healthcare than nearly all developed countries (Switzerland is close), and but we get only mediocre benefits in terms of the level of healthcare outcomes. This disparity is a consequence of many, complex public, corporate and individual choices, and perhaps unintended consequences. When we talk about lowering healthcare costs, for instance, we need to consider that reality that most of the costs in the healthcare services sector are the costs of people. Not just healthcare providers, but administrators, billing services, insurance companies, drug company researchers, nursing home operators, etc. So, if we want to reduce healthcare costs, we should consider where else some of these people will find jobs? Healthcare services may be taking the place of manufacturing in our economy; providing skilled and semi-skilled jobs in substantial numbers and a something like middle-class compensation.

Year to year premium increases ( some up to 30%) where common before the ACA for those of us who didn't have employers who provided low cost insurance.
Since the ACA our premiums have gone down along with our deductibles.

Two thoughts here. Getting a policy on my state health exchange for a comparable plan costs twice as much for me as my retiree plan. My retiree plan is more expensive than what current employees pay.  Again, I'm not whining about this, just pointing out there's been a lot written over the past two years about the cost of premiums only rising 2-3% and maybe that was simply meant for state exchange rates. I am happy that people like you are paying less, but others are paying more.

I have said this elsewhere. The ACA has done some good things for those who were previously uninsured or who were paying very high rates for pre-existing conditions.

In my case, I was laid off four years ago by a large corporation and have retiree medical insurance for my wife and myself. I appreciate that the premium cost is half or less than what it would cost us on our state exchange. In addition, we are basically healthy people and make minimal use of the medical system.

I have seen our premiums increase 25% from 2012 to 2013. The same increase 2013 to 2014 and a 20% increase over the past year. We are on a basic indemnity plan that will cost $7,500 next year plus out-of-pocket deductibles of $2,500 per person. So beyond an annual physical exam and certain preventative procedures that have no additional cost, it will cost at least $10K to access the 70% of major medical costs covered by the plan.

I am not complaining about this retiree benefit, just pointing out what it costs to access medical care for a modest middle class retiree. I was led to believe that ACA would reduce costs overall for most and cause modest increases for some. However, year-to-year premium increases of 20-25% was not what I was expecting.

Here's perhaps a strange comment from a person who knows nothing about music but loves to listen to music:

What I loved about watching and listening to this video is that I could see HOW the individual sounds were being made.

For example, I could hear and see the sounds created by the bass player as he plucked individual strings.

I would assume that such a realization is always possible, so maybe it's when there are words that draw our attention that we don't pay as close attention to the actual making of the musical sounds?

Whatever the reason, I very much enjoyed watching these talented artists make beautiful sounds.

QE is what we are forced to do, because we can't get a better form of stimulus through our broken political process.

If inflationistas want to limit QE, they could do any of the better ideas for more efficient direct stimulus.

They don't opposed just QE. They oppose the whole idea of government helping us recover.

Just watched. The QE-increase-fragility argument is officially the new argument for inflationistas, conveniently cooked with some kind of radical spice which makes it appealing even to people on the left ("it's finance ruining the thing!"). As Paul said, the amount of peculiar mechanisms holding and entirely conventional mechanisms not holding which is necessary for all of this to work is just too much.

What is perhaps interesting is the underlying conception of the financial-real relationship in a depression. Actually, as if there was no depression. Finance leads the way, monetary authorities can guide a bit but nothing "unconventional" will work because there is no big hole to fix in terms of uncertainty. Then for some reason, which is of course not difficult to justify *in general*, finance takes more risk than real investors, which replicates trade cycle stories on the heterogeneity of capital once being told for firms within the real economy. The idea that a depression environment essentially alters the rules of the game and puts central banks firmly ahead in setting up what is going to happen is ignored. Not to speak of the fact that maybe just maybe, the (limited) financial volatility which has resurged after the crisis might have more to do with permanent search by unregulated traders in the context of a general presumption that safe assets will in any case be found. Nono, another decade-long boom, just because we already saw one. Read some history.
I had the same thought about over-cooking the asparagus. Has anyone tried this recipe without cooking it before baking?

Hard to believe you'd want or need that much asparagus for this recipe. I used maybe 1/2 lb. and it looked about the same as the photo accompanying this recipe. I think someone goofed on the amount of asparagus.

Also, if you cook even to crisp-tender stage before baking, the asparagus has to be overcooked after cooking another 35 minutes. Mine was. My advice: skip cooking the asparagus in water. The asparagus will be cooked after baking 35 minutes at 350 degrees.

As European I can only smile at the language used here: as if the US were even ose to being a leader on climate change... What a joke if by leaser is meant second biggest polluter and that without the rightful justification of developong countries such as China stating that in their phase of development high energy consumption is normal. Take Germany as a real example of a leader in climate friendly policies. A whole industrial power house is transformed into a green economy. As so often, nobody beats the US in marketing itself. Get real by starting to insulate your houses as it is normal in first world countries and by taken gas guzzlers off the street etc.

BB, if this was 1973, I might agree with you more. However, with automakers in the US agreeing to stringent fuel economy requirements stretching until 2025, which because of global manufacturing system requirements will basically apply worldwide, the demand for oil is going to go down. I assume new technologies will also lessen our dependence upon oil. China is choking in smog; population densities will require them to clean up their act.

There might be a short-term need for Canadian crude, but long-term and for the environment, Obama made the right call.

When put in the context of the disasters President Obama inherited from the previous administration (remember when we were losing 800,000 jobs per month?) he's done reasonably well.

If the Congress cared about jobs it would pass an infrastructure bill that would borrow money at the current near zero real interest rates and fix roads, bridges, and railroads, yielding great economic benefits (and many tens of times more jobs than this pipeline would have temporarily generated).

This pipeline was nothing more than a gift to the oil companies and Canada. The tar sands is the most toxic of all crude and Canada want's to get rid of it while they can. By delaying the decision the pipeline may have become obsolete as the price both financially and environmentally to extract it from the Alberta tar sands is only cost effective when oil prices are high. As for jobs, Yes, a couple years of temporary jobs required for construction, but after that only about 30 to maintain it. As for any other advantage, the refined product would go on the global market and would have no effect on the US economy.

Thank you President Obama; good timing and good decision.

I find it troubling that so many readers dismiss Keystone's employment figures because the bulk of the jobs - high-paying jobs- would last "only two years."  By that reasoning, no construction project provides employment benefits, because none are "permanent."  For a laborer who is out of work, a two-year high-paying job could be a lifesaver.  What's worse, with no real environmental benefits, blocking Keystone is merely a symbolic victory for its opponents; a feel-good measure and opportunity for Obama and McKibben to burnish their green credentials.  At the cost of jobs, albeit unfashionable jobs, science and sound procedure.  This is not good government.

The GOP has it backwards.  They are the ones who have politicized the science of global warming and climate change.  The science of global warming is not open for debate, it is a known fact.  If we don't wish to destroy our world, we the people need to change the way our world works, and that includes where our energy comes from.  Building more infrastructure for burning oil is just plan dumb.  It is investing in a dead end future.

The intellectual arrogance of both the left and the right make discussion, politics and compromise impossible. When we are infallible we are easy prey.

Three issues need further elucidation -- they are --One, is oil from Canada already coming into the US; two, if it is already coming to the USA, how is it coming, who benefits from this mode of shipping oil to the US (from Canada); and third, was the oil pipeline only another, albeit, more secure and with greater capacity, route to an item already coming to the US.  Now, the issue is who are the beneficiaries of this Presidential decision? And an allied issue, is the Pipe Line a better and more secure, and less environmentally dangerous option than the existing routes of brining in the oil from Canada?  A fuller account of the entire matter will be welcome!

That's a whole steaming load right there. Thousands of hectares of land has been reclaimed. Oil sands products are being shipped to the US in record numbers but more expensively, dangerously and at a greater environmental cost, by rail...and older pipelines. Most of the extra energy being used is being provided by natural gas, a product Northern Canada has in abundance, much of which would be flared off as part of the gas production process, and has been diverted for use in the oil sands projects.

Fairy tales are more fun than facts but that doesn't make them true.
